sharks.name: Great White Shark
sharks.fun_fact: Although often depicted as ferocious man-eaters, Great White Sharks typically account for less than 10 fatal attacks on humans each year. Most bites occur because sharks are curious or mistake humans with other prey like turtles.

sharks.name: Great Hammerhead Shark
sharks.fun_fact: Great hammerheads can be distinguished by the relatively straight front margin of their head, also called the cephalofoil. Other hammerhead species' heads are more arched or scalloped.

sharks.name: Shortfin Mako Shark
sharks.fun_fact: Shortfin mako sharks are the fastest known shark species, reaching speeds as high as 46mph in short bursts.

sharks.name: Tiger Shark
sharks.fun_fact: Tiger sharks the widest food spectrum of all sharks, and have a reputation as the 'garbage-cans' of the ocean, with a wide variety of man-made objects such as license plates found in their stomachs after capture.

sharks.name: Bull Shark
sharks.fun_fact: Bull sharks are able to thrive in both salt and fresh water. Due to their wide-ranging habitat and relatively aggressive, territorial behavior, they pose a higher potential threat to humans. However, only 25 fatal attacks have been recorded since 1580.

sharks.name: Nurse Shark
sharks.fun_fact: Nurse sharks are an extremely important species in shark research, as they respond well to capture and life in captivity. However, they are ranked fourth in documented bites on humans due to the higher number of interactions that occur in captivity. Due to their calm, sedentary nature, divers may be less cautious when interacting with them in the wild.

sharks.name: Whale Shark
sharks.fun_fact: The whale shark is not only the largest shark; it is the largest non-cetacean (the group which includes whales) animal. Like many whales, they feed almost exclusively on plankton and small fish and pose no threat to humans.

sharks.name: Sand Tiger Shark
sharks.fun_fact: They are the most widely kept shark in public aquariums due to their tolerance for captivity. Sand tiger sharks often swim with their mouths open and teeth displayed, giving them a menacing appearance; however, they have a relatively placid demeanor
